data.title: Uncaught Error: end pattern with unmatched parenthesis
data.body:
[Enter steps to reproduce below:]
1. ...Open custom wordpress plugin file in development
2. ...Change Document Mode in bottom right from PHP to wordpress

**Atom Version**: 0.179.0
**System**: Microsoft Windows 8.1
**Thrown From**: Atom Core
### Stack Trace

Uncaught Error: end pattern with unmatched parenthesis

```
At C:\Users\Daniel\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.179.0\resources\app\node_modules\first-mate\lib\scanner.js:31

Error: end pattern with unmatched parenthesis
  at Error (native)
  at Scanner.module.exports.Scanner.createScanner (C:\Users\Daniel\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.179.0\resources\app\node_modules\first-mate\lib\scanner.js:31:24)
  at Scanner.module.exports.Scanner.getScanner (C:\Users\Daniel\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.179.0\resources\app\node_modules\first-mate\lib\scanner.js:37:31)
  at Scanner.module.exports.Scanner.findNextMatch (C:\Users\Daniel\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.179.0\resources\app\node_modules\first-mate\lib\scanner.js:56:22)

  at Grammar.module.exports.Grammar.tokenizeLine (C:\Users\Daniel\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.179.0\resources\app\node_modules\first-mate\lib\grammar.js:125:39)
  at TokenizedBuffer.module.exports.TokenizedBuffer.buildTokenizedLineForRow (C:\Users\Daniel\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.179.0\resources\app\src\tokenized-buffer.js:482:28)
  at TokenizedBuffer.module.exports.TokenizedBuffer.tokenizeNextChunk (C:\Users\Daniel\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.179.0\resources\app\src\tokenized-buffer.js:265:43)
  at C:\Users\Daniel\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.179.0\resources\app\src\tokenized-buffer.js:247:26
  at C:\Users\Daniel\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.179.0\resources\app\node_modules\roaster\node_modules\underscore\underscore.js:666:47

```


``` coffee
No dev packages
```

data.title: Document a way to run commands (and from init.coffee)
data.body:
How to programatically run a command such as `core:cancel`? I had to figure it out since I failed to find how.

This works:

`$('atom-text-editor').dispatchEvent(new CustomEvent('core:cancel'))`

However it doesn't from init.coffee, because `$` is not defined there (I believe init.coffee should have the same environment as in the Developer Tools console, but that's a different issue).

I suggest to create a Docs page explaining commands, how to run them programatically, and in particular how to run them from init.coffee.

Thanks - VIctor

data.title: Fix typos in API docs
data.body: The word `optional` was misspelled as `optinal` two times in the API docs. This PR corrects those errors.

data.title: Unable to install plugins on Ubuntu 14.04
data.body:
All of a sudden all of my plugin updates or installations fail with the following error log:

```
npm ERR! addLocal Could not install /tmp/d-115114-13730-zx3j8u/package.tgz
npm ERR! Linux 3.13.0-45-generic
npm ERR! argv "/opt/atom/resources/app/apm/bin/node"     "/opt/atom/resources/app/apm/node_modules/npm/bin/npm-cli.js" "--globalconfig" "/opt/atom/resources/app/apm/.apmrc" "--userconfig" "/home/mehrlich/Seafile/dotfiles/.atom/.apmrc" "install" "/tmp/d-115114-13730-zx3j8u/package.tgz" "--target=0.21.0" "--arch=x64"
npm ERR! node v0.10.35
npm ERR! npm  v2.3.0
npm ERR! path /var/lib/jenkins
npm ERR! code EACCES
npm ERR! errno 3

npm ERR! Error: EACCES, mkdir '/var/lib/jenkins'
npm ERR!  { [Error: EACCES, mkdir '/var/lib/jenkins'] errno: 3, code: 'EACCES', path: '/var/lib/jenkins' }
npm ERR! 
npm ERR! Please try running this command again as root/Administrator.

npm ERR! Please include the following file with any support request:
npm ERR!     /tmp/apm-install-dir-115114-13730-1ssxjoq/npm-debug.log
```

Is there something messed up with my configuration or is this a bug in atom? It's pretty troubling that it is trying to access the privileged directory `/var/lib`. Also note that ALL packages fail with `/var/lib/jenkins`, this path never changes.

data.title: Memory error when setting ATOM_HOME and lauching atom
data.body:
Running the .zip version of atom on a USB stick and trying to make it portable, I have found that to set the ATOM_HOME, I should create a script like this:

```
SET ATOM_HOME="E:\Web Stuff & Tools\Atom\.atom"
atom
```

Running that script creates the following error:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6568235/6200090/e7bf9546-b45f-11e4-9b99-c7de4694b50c.png)

Any ideas why?

data.title: windows building environment update failed
Update is not transparent enough
data.body:
When I update Atom, what happens is the Update option turns into an "Updating" message and stays like that indefinitely. I have no way of knowing if the update is actually working, if it is done, or anything else of the sort. It is not until I close and restart Atom that it tells me I am using a new version.

A significant improvement to this would be to do one of the following:

1) Emulate how GitHub for Windows works--silently download the update and prompt the user to install it at their convenience

2) Keep the manual update process but give more information during the process such as % downloaded, % installed, prompt to reopen when done (if necessary), etc.

3) Include Atom updates within the package/theme update system so that you are automatically notified of an update and are provided some GUI information

My vote would probably go with option 1. It's automated and non-intrusive.

Uninstall everything or ?

data.title: Atom 179 won't open on Windows
data.body:
I recently installed Atom 179 and it refuses to open new windows. I tried to close it and reopen it and now it's not opening at all. When I click my pinned taskbar icon a single atom process pops up in my taskbar then quickly disappears. If I open the exe manually from appdata, I don't even get that.

Reverting back to 177 works great, I immediately get 4 processes and Atom pops up as expected.

data.title: Paste and Match Style not working on Mac
data.body:
http://support.apple.com/en-us/HT201236

Command-Shift-Option-V (the default keyboard shortcut for Paste and Match Style) doesn't seem to work in Atom as a method to paste as plain text. 

Ideally, that keyboard shortcut would work the same way as it does in TextEdit (while TextEdit is in plain text mode).

Running Atom 0.179.0 on OSX 10.10.2

data.title: please implement
data.body:
When dividing the atom window in to multiple sections have a way to resize proportions.

ps: I'm new to Github

data.title: Renaming long filenames: scrollbar hides text
data.body:
Steps:
1. Select a file to rename in treeview
1. Press F2
1. The small dialog to rename file shows up on the top

Here the filepath should be fully visibile. Instead, because the filename is wider than field width, the horizontal scrollbar shows up. But that overlaps and partially hides the filename itself (see screenshot).

HTH
Cheers

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3185573/6191547/a0e9f6f8-b3aa-11e4-96ef-f8a9cf938350.png)

data.title: Atom close/crash if i drag/move a firefox tab over it
data.body:
Tested with Firefox last stable & developer edition (Aurora).
If i open a new tab or one with content, and i drag it away (to open a new window), and move the cursor over Atom it closes.

Here the shell output:

``` bash
mfkinder@wk-boe001:~$ atom
mfkinder@wk-boe001:~$ [14953:0213/170206:ERROR:browser_main_loop.cc(164)] Running without the SUID sandbox! See https://code.google.com/p/chromium/wiki/LinuxSUIDSandboxDevelopment for more information on developing with the sandbox on.
[14983:0213/170206:INFO:renderer_main.cc(211)] Renderer process started
App load time: 314ms
[14953:0213/170208:INFO:CONSOLE(11)] "activate linter-jshint", source: /home/mfkinder/.atom/packages/linter-jshint/lib/init.coffee (11)
[14953:0213/170208:INFO:CONSOLE(79)] "Window load time: 1688ms", source: file:///usr/share/atom/resources/app/static/index.js (79)
The program 'atom' received an X Window System error.
This probably reflects a bug in the program.
The error was 'BadAtom (invalid Atom parameter)'.
  (Details: serial 495 error_code 5 request_code 20 minor_code 0)
  (Note to programmers: normally, X errors are reported asynchronously;
   that is, you will receive the error a while after causing it.
   To debug your program, run it with the --sync command line
   option to change this behavior. You can then get a meaningful
   backtrace from your debugger if you break on the gdk_x_error() function.)
```

Here tested with "--safe"

``` bash
mfkinder@wk-boe001:~$ atom --safe
mfkinder@wk-boe001:~$ [14753:0213/170133:ERROR:browser_main_loop.cc(164)] Running without the SUID sandbox! See https://code.google.com/p/chromium/wiki/LinuxSUIDSandboxDevelopment for more information on developing with the sandbox on.
[14783:0213/170133:INFO:renderer_main.cc(211)] Renderer process started
App load time: 303ms
[14753:0213/170135:INFO:CONSOLE(79)] "Window load time: 1552ms", source: file:///usr/share/atom/resources/app/static/index.js (79)
The program 'atom' received an X Window System error.
This probably reflects a bug in the program.
The error was 'BadAtom (invalid Atom parameter)'.
  (Details: serial 448 error_code 5 request_code 20 minor_code 0)
  (Note to programmers: normally, X errors are reported asynchronously;
   that is, you will receive the error a while after causing it.
   To debug your program, run it with the --sync command line
   option to change this behavior. You can then get a meaningful
   backtrace from your debugger if you break on the gdk_x_error() function.)
```

OS: Ubuntu 14.10 x64
Plugins installed:

data.title: Settings View not opening
data.body:
I am unable to open the settings through the command palette or using the keys `Ctrl-,`. Using the Menu however, I am able to access it through Edit > Preferences. 

I have verified this is still an issue in Atom's Safe Mode (`--safe`) and that there are no errors in the console. 

My setup:
**OS:** Ubuntu 14.04
**Atom:** 0.180.0-2dac7fd
**settings-view:** 0.181.0

data.title: Multiple processes spawn spontaneously.
data.body:
I have caught a bug that will spawn multiple Atom processes mostly when the main window gains focus. Some are killed but there are more and more being added as time passes and it leads to a 100% CPU usage and more than 80% memory usage (about 8GB of RAM on my machine). In the screenshot below you can see what I mean (NOTE: There are more than 40 processes and was unable to include all in a single screenshot).

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/939247/6189672/770c4d80-b36a-11e4-8e31-8970f7c8c7c8.png)

data.title: Uncaught Error: Atom can only handle files < 2MB for now.
data.body:
Uncaught Error: Atom can only handle files < 2MB for now.

**Atom Version**: 0.158.0
**System**: linux 3.13.0-37-generic
**Thrown From**: Atom Core
### Steps To Reproduce
1. ...
2. ...
### Stack Trace

```
At /usr/share/atom/resources/app/src/project.js:461

Error: Atom can only handle files < 2MB for now.
  at Project.module.exports.Project.buildBuffer (/usr/share/atom/resources/app/src/project.js:461:15)
  at Project.module.exports.Project.bufferForPath (/usr/share/atom/resources/app/src/project.js:438:63)
  at Project.module.exports.Project.open (/usr/share/atom/resources/app/src/project.js:392:19)
  at Workspace.module.exports.Workspace.openUriInPane (/usr/share/atom/resources/app/src/workspace.js:482:29)
```

data.title: Export documented API through require('atom')
data.body:
I think the [documented Atom API](https://atom.io/docs/api/v0.179.0/Atom) classes should be exported through require('atom'). At least for all classes where it would make sense for a package developer to instantiate. e.g. Workspace shouldn't be exported since no one needs to instantiate that, but Disposable, and CompositeDisposable should be exported since it makes sense for a package developer to instantiate them.

That's pretty much how things already work... Except for `File` and `Directory` which are documented, but not exported. This causes two problems.
1. First reading through the API, I see those classes and want to use them, but when I try `{File} = require 'atom'` it doesn't work. Which is very confusing since it does work for the rest of the API.
2. The workaround is to including the underlying `pathwatcher` package into my own package. That's fine, but makes my package bigger, slower to load, and now I've got an extra dependency to manage. It seems unnecessary since `File` and `Directory` are already a documented part of Atom.

Here's a pull request that exports those classes #5499

data.title: File Scroll while typing (Bug or Feature ?)
data.body:
after updating atom to the current version 0.179 , when write a large text, it will be hidden behind the status bar, but i found an option called scroll past end in core settings, after activating it it solved the problem, is this a new feature ? or a bug ? 

check screenshot there is a line behind the status bar
![screenshot from 2015-02-13 11 47 23](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4104127/6185443/fcbd5a94-b376-11e4-81f6-36da215bc73d.png)

data.title: Replace directoryExistsSync() with Directory::existsSync().
data.body: This makes it possible to remove a TODO in `GitRepositoryProvider`.

data.title: Package gets duplicated when moved to Atom Core Packages
data.body:
Original post here: https://discuss.atom.io/t/language-csharp-package-appears-twice/14867

**Language-csharp package appears twice**

After the [recent 0.178.0 release](https://atom.io/releases) (_Atom now includes C# syntax highlighting by default_), the language-csharp package appears twice in my "Installed Package" list - once under Community Packages, and once under Core Packages.

![fa75766fb9ca7157](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/517857/6182518/c6de7932-b388-11e4-8b62-4ff64ac6275c.png)

I manually disabled the Community Packages version, but there is no option to uninstall it.

I was able to manually delete the Community Packages version in `~/.atom/packages/languages-csharp` via command line, which is a temporary workaround to the problem.

Ideally, when a package is moved to Atom Core, the existing Community Package is uninstalled and settings are transferred to the Atom Core version.

Additional info: OS X 10.10.2, Atom 0.177.0/0.178.0

Thanks. :sparkles:

data.title: Try to set the Project's repo if it does not have one when a new Reposit...
data.body:
...oryProvider is registered.

I tested this using my test `HgRepositoryProvider`. Now when I run the following from the
command line:

```
atom <path-to-directory-with-hg-repository>
```

And then run the following in the console:

```
atom.project.getRepositories()
```

I get an array with an `HgRepository` in it. Previously, I got an empty array because the
`Project`'s paths were set before my `HgRepositoryProvider` was registered.
